questions.text: 11-year-old Riya is brought by her mother with a severe headache. The headache began gradually approximately 2 hours earlier, is bifrontal, and is slightly worse on the right side. The girl feels as though "someone is pounding on her head." Approximately 30 minutes before her headache started, she noted changes in her vision and saw "dark spots" while watching TV. The girl had never had headaches until 2 weeks before the presentation when she had a similar episode. Today she had a single episode of emesis and still complains of nausea. She is lying quietly in bed with her eyes closed. Her vitals, physical and neurological examination are normal When asked to sit up, she moves very slowly and carefully. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Administer ibuprofen and counsel the family

options.label: B
options.text: Obtain a computed tomography scan of the head

options.label: D
options.text: Obtain a magnetic resonance image of the brain

questions.correct_answer: A. Administer ibuprofen and counsel the family
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Administer ibuprofen and counsel the family This patient's presentation of a severe headache of gradual onset associated with nausea, vomiting, and photophobia, which is increasing on movement and a visual aura is most consistent with migraine headache with aura. First-line treatment of acute migraine headaches in Children aged < 12 Supportive management lying in a dark, quiet room with a cool cloth on the forehead Acetaminophen Or A nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory agent e.g., Ibuprofen

Highyeild:

Headaches are a common chief complaint in the pediatric population and can have both benign and potentially dangerous etiologies. Migraine headaches are the most common form of headaches in the pediatric population and occur befor e age 20 in 50% of cases .

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B . Obtain a computed tomography scan of the head And D. Obtain a magnetic resonance image of the brain in the context of a normal neurologic examination that does not require neuroimaging . Option: C. A lumbar puncture- is the most appropriate next step for a patient in whom meningitis or pseudotumor cerebri (idiopathic intracranial hypertension) is suspected Given that this patient is afebrile and has no history of recent illness, meningitis is less likely.

Extraedge:

Indications for neuroimaging in a child with a headache: History of coordination difficulties Presence of numbness/tingling/focal neurologic signs History of a headache that causes awakening from sleep History of increasing headache frequency

questions.text: 29-year-old Mrs. Kapoor comes to the hospital due to frequent episodes of more than 5 attacks per month of headache which are moderate to severe, left-sided, throbbing pain associated with nausea and occasional vomiting, preceded by a tingling sensation in the right hand that gradually involves the right arm and face and is followed by numbness lasting <1 hour. Now she is missing her work because of the headaches. There is a family history of depression. Which of the following is most likely to be helpful in preventing this patient's headaches?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Topiramate This patient has Classical migraine headaches with Aura as evidenced by recurrent episodes of severe, left-sided, throbbing headaches associated with nausea and vomiting and often preceded by an aura (eg, progressive right-sided tingling sensation followed by numbness) .there are more than 4 attacks per month which are incapacitating (missing work), indicates the need of Prophylactic therapy for this patient. Among the given options, only Topiramate is FDA approved for Prophylaxis of Migraines.

Highyeild:

PREVENTIVE TREATMENTS FOR MIGRAINE Indications- Increasing frequency of migraine attacks with attacks that are either unresponsive or poorly responsive to abortive treatments four or more attacks a month. Commonly used Preventives: Beta-blockers Propranolol Metoprolol Timolol Anticonvulsants Valproate Topiramate Tricyclic antidepressants Amitriptyline Dosulepin Nortriptyline Venlafaxine Monoclonal antibodies against CGRP approved for migraine prophylaxis- Erenumab(s.c.) galcanezumab(s.c.) Eptinezumab(i.v.) Serotonin and tryptamine antagonist Pizotifen Neuromodulation Single-pulse transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) Onabotulinum toxin type A(Chronic migraine )

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A.Beta-interferon- is a disease-modifying drug indicated for chronic maintenance therapy in patients with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis. It is not indicated for the treatment or prophylaxis of migraine headaches. Option: B. Glucocorticoids- can be given with other abortive migraine medications for acute migraines but play no role in the prophylaxis of migraines due to their long-term side effects (eg, hyperglycemia, osteoporosis). Option: C.Sertraline - a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor , is an antidepressant and is not commonly used in migraine . Antidepressants that can be used are amitriptyline and venlafaxine.

Extraedge:

TABLE 430-6 Preventive Treatments in Migraine DRUG DOSE SELECTED SIDE EFFECTS Beta-blocker Propranolol Metoprolol 40-120 mg bid 25-100 mg bid Reduced energy Tiredness Postural symptoms Contraindicated in asthma Antidepressants Amitriptyline Dosulepin Nortriptyline Venlafaxine 10-75 mg at night 25-75 mg at night 25-75 mg at night 75-150 mg/d Drowsiness Note: Some patients may only need a total dose of 10 mg, although generally 1-1.5 mg/kg body weight is required Anticonvulsants Topiramate Valproate 25-200 mg/d 400-600 mg bid Paresthesias Cognitive symptoms Weight loss Glaucoma Caution with nephrolithiasis Drowsiness Weight gain Tremor Hair loss Fetal abnormalities Hematologic or liver abnormalities Serotonergic drugs Pizotifen 0.5-2 mg qd Weight gain CGRP antagonists Eptinezumab Erenumab Fremanezumab Galcanezumab Rimegepant 100 or 300 mg IV every 12 weeks 70 or 140 mg SC monthly 225 mg monthly or 675 mg q3 months, SC 240 mg loading then 120 mg monthly, SC 75 mg every other day Nasopharyngitis Nasopharyngitis, constipation Injection site reactions Nasopharyngitis Nausea abdominal pain/ dyspepsia Other classe Flunarizine Candesartan Memantine Melatonin 5-15 mg qd 4-24 mg daily 5-20 mg daily 3-12 mg nightly Drowsiness Weight gain Depression Parkinsonism Dizziness Dizziness, tiredness Drowsiness Neuromodulation Single-pulse transcranial magnetic stimulation (STMS 4-24 pulses per day Lightheadedness Tingling Tinnitus Chronic migraine Onabotulinum toxin types A 155 U Loss of brow furrow No convincing evidence from controlled trials Verapamil Controlled trials demonstrate no effect Nimodipine Clonidine Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors: fluoxetine Commonly used preventives are listed with typical doses and common side effects. Not all listed medicines are approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration; local regulations and guidelines should be consulted. *Not available in the United States.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female who is currently 8 weeks pregnant presents with a severe headache. The headache is located over the right side of her head with a severe, throbbing pain associated with nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia. Her neurological examination is normal. She has an urgent magnetic resonance imaging of the brain that is also normal. Which of the following would be a reasonable first-line agent to treat her headache?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Acetaminophen Patient has unilateral, throbbing pain associated with Nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia all these point toward a diagnosis of Migraine.

Highyeild:

Migraine treatment in pregnancy A cetaminophen First line Abortive treatment for Migraine Pregnancy category C . Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs Ibuprofen, naproxen, and diclofenac can be used in the first and second trimesters but should be avoided in the third trimester because they can cause premature closure of the ductus arteriosus.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A.Sumatriptan -is considered a third-line treatment and is a pregnancy category B. Option: B. Morphine -Opioids are generally avoided for headache therapy, either abortive or preventive, due to the risk of medication overuse headache , as well as rebound headaches. Option: C. Ergotamine- is pregnancy category X and should be avoided at all costs

questions.text: 24-year-old Mrs. Sinha with asthma has several years of history of recurrent headaches that are severe, pulsatile, and unilateral in nature, with associated nausea. The headaches occur at least twice per week and tend to last about half a day, after which she feels “worthless” for the remainder of the day. She refused a trial of oral birth control pills due to religious beliefs. Based on the suspected headache diagnosis, which of the following would be appropriate first-line daily therapy?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Amitriptyline The patient suffers from migraine(Pulsatile, unilateral headache ) given the frequency of her headaches ( more than 4 attacks per month ), daily preventive therapy is indicated. Amitriptyline is considered a first-line migraine therapy and is safe both in the Reproductive age group ( category C in pregnancy )and with a history of asthma.

Highyeild:

PREVENTIVE TREATMENTS FOR MIGRAINE Indications: Increasing frequency of migraine attacks with attacks that are either unresponsive or poorly responsive to abortive treatments four or more attacks a month. Commonly used Preventives: Beta-blockers Propranolol Metoprolol Timolol Anticonvulsants Valproate Topiramate Tricyclic antidepressants Amitriptyline Dosulepin Nortriptyline Venlafaxine Monoclonal antibodies against CGRP approved for migraine prophylaxis- Erenumab(s.c.) galcanezumab(s.c.) Eptinezumab(i.v.) Serotonin and tryptamine antagonist Pizotifen Neuromodulation Single-pulse transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) Onabotulinum toxin type A(Chronic migraine )

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A.Sumatriptan - is useful for abortive therapy in case of migraine. Option: B. Topiramate- may be efficacious for migraine prevention , but is associated with teratogenicity ; given the patient’s refusal to use birth control , these would be less favored . Option: D.Propranolol -may be efficacious for migraine prevention in the reproductive age group. But, it is contraindicated with a history of asthma.

Extraedge:

DRUG DOSE SELECTED SIDE EFFECTS Beta-blocker Propranolol Metoprolol 40-120 mg bid 25-100 mg bid Reduced energy Tiredness Postural symptoms Contraindicated in asthma Antidepressants Amitriptyline Dosulepin Nortriptyline Venlafaxine 10-75 mg at night 25-75 mg at night 25-75 mg at night 75-150 mg/d Drowsiness Note: Some patients may only need a total dose of 10 mg, although generally 1-1.5 mg/kg body weight is required Anticonvulsants Topiramate Valproate 25-200 mg/d 400-600 mg bid Paresthesias Cognitive symptoms Weight loss Glaucoma Caution with nephrolithiasis Drowsiness Weight gain Tremor Hair loss Fetal abnormalities Hematologic or liver abnormalities Serotonergic drugs Pizotifen 0.5-2 mg qd Weight gain CGRP antagonists Eptinezumab Erenumab Fremanezumab Galcanezumab Rimegepant 100 or 300 mg IV every 12 weeks 70 or 140 mg SC monthly 225 mg monthly or 675 mg q3 months, SC 240 mg loading then 120 mg monthly, SC 75 mg every other day Nasopharyngitis Nasopharyngitis, constipation Injection site reactions Nasopharyngitis Nausea abdominal pain/ dyspepsia Other classes Flunarizine Candesartan Memantine Melatonin 5-15 mg qd 4-24 mg daily 5-20 mg daily 3-12 mg nightly Drowsiness Weight gain Depression Parkinsonism Dizziness Dizziness, tiredness Drowsiness Neuromodulation Single-pulse transcranial magnetic stimulation (STMS 4-24 pulses per day Lightheadedness Tingling Tinnitus Chronic migraine onabotulinum toxin type A 155 U Loss of brow furrow No convincing evidence from controlled trials Verapamil Controlled trials demonstrate no effect Nimodipine Clonidine Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors: fluoxetine Commonly used preventives are listed with typical doses and common side effects. Not all listed medicines are approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration; local regulations and guidelines should be consulted. *Not available in the United States.

questions.text: 24-year-old Priya suffers from recurrent severe, lateralized, pulsatile headaches with light and sound sensitivity. These tend to occur during her menses and may last for up to 3 days at a time. Which of the following would be the best choice for a first-line therapeutic trial?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Perimenstrual scheduled naproxen For women who suffer migraine headaches( as the patient has Unilateral pulsatile headache with sensitivity to light and sound ) during menses but not at other times during the month, short-term prophylactic therapy may be efficacious for migraine prevention. Scheduled non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs or triptans may be started 2–3 days before menses and continued for up to 2 weeks after menses as a first-line therapeutic trial.

Highyeild:

Menses-related Migraine headache Prevention taken during the menses Ergotamine Estrogen patches Rimegepant 75 mg po Treatment non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs Triptans Dihydroergotamine nasal spray

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A.Opioids are generally avoided for headache therapy, either abortive or preventive, due to risk of medication overuse headache , as well as rebound headaches Option: C.Propranolol There is no evidence of efficacy with short-term prophylaxis using beta-blockers . Option: D. Valproate is a Category X teratogenic agent hence not preferred in women of reproductive age.

Extraedge:

Treatments Clinical Stratification of Acute Specific Migraine CLINICAL SITUATION TREATMENT OPTIONS Failed NSAIDs/analgesics First Sumatriptan 50 mg or 100 mg PO Almotriptan 12.5 mg PO Rizatriptan 10 mg PO Eletriptan 40 mg PO Zolmitriptan 2.5 mg PO Rimegepant 75 mg Ubrogepant 50 or 100 mg Lasmiditan 50, 100, or 200 mg Slower effect/better tolerability Naratriptan 2.5 mg PO Frovatriptan 2.5 mg PO Infrequent headache Ergotamine/caffeine 1-2/100 mg PO Dihydroergotamine nasal spray 2 mg Early nausea or difficulties taking tablets Zolmitriptan 5 mg nasal spray Sumatriptan 20 mg nasal spray Rizatriptan 10 mg MLT wafer Headache recurrence Ergotamine 2 mg (most effective PR/usually with caffeine) Naratriptan 2.5 mg PO Almotriptan 12.5 mg PO Eletriptan 40 mg Rimegepant 75 mg Ubrogepant 50 or 100 mg Tolerating acute treatments poorly Naratriptan 2.5 mg Tolerating acute treatments poorly Almotriptan 12.5 mg Rimegepant 75 mg Ubrogepant 50, 100 mg Single-pulse transcranial magnetic stimulation Noninvasive vagus nerve stimulation Early vomiting Zolmitriptan 5 mg nasal spray Sumatriptan 25 mg PR Sumatriptan 6 mg SC Menses-related headache Prevention Ergotamine po at night Estrogen patches Rimegepant 75 mg po taken during the menses Treatment Triptans Very rapidly developing symptoms Zolmitriptan 5 mg nasal spray Sumatriptan 6 mg SC Dihydroergotamine 1 mg IM Abbreviation: NSAIDs. nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man is evaluated for a 6 months history of increasingly frequent episodes of migraine with aura. The patient has had migraine with aura since the age of 23 years. Auras involve 15 to 20 minutes of twinkling lights and visual blurring. Migraine episode frequency has increased from once to twice monthly. Acetaminophen, ibuprofen, and naproxen were each discontinued after becoming ineffective with the head now lasting 24 hours. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sumatriptan This patient should be treated with Sumatriptan as His migraine is no longer responsive to NSAIDS .

Highyeild:

Failed NSAIDs/analgesics Migraine First-tier Sumatriptan Almotriptan Rizatriptan Eletriptan Zolmitriptan Imegepant Ubrogepant Lasmiditan Slower effect/better tolerability Naratriptan Frovatriptan Infrequent headache Ergotamine caffeine Dihydroergotamine nasal spray

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A.Hydrocodone-Opioids are generally avoided for headache therapy, either abortive or preventive, due to risk of medication overuse headache , as well as rebound headaches Option: B & D. Topiramate & Verapamil -This patient has only 2 episodes of migraine per month so prophylactic medication is not indicated.

Extraedge:

Clinical Stratification of Acute Specific Migraine: CLINICAL SITUATION TREATMENT OPTIONS Failed NSAIDs/analgesics First Sumatriptan 50 mg or 100 mg PO Almotriptan 12.5 mg PO Rizatriptan 10 mg PO Eletriptan 40 mg PO Zolmitriptan 2.5 mg PO Rimegepant 75 mg Ubrogepant 50 or 100 mg Lasmiditan 50, 100, or 200 mg Slower effect/better tolerability Naratriptan 2.5 mg PO Frovatriptan 2.5 mg PO Infrequent headache Ergotamine/caffeine 1-2/100 mg PO Dihydroergotamine nasal spray 2 mg Early nausea or difficulties taking tablets Zolmitriptan 5 mg nasal spray Sumatriptan 20 mg nasal spray Rizatriptan 10 mg MLT wafer Headache recurrence Ergotamine 2 mg (most effective PR/usually with caffeine) Naratriptan 2.5 mg PO Almotriptan 12.5 mg PO Eletriptan 40 mg Rimegepant 75 mg Ubrogepant 50 or 100 mg Tolerating acute treatments poorly Naratriptan 2.5 mg Tolerating acute treatments poorly Almotriptan 12.5 mg Rimegepant 75 mg Ubrogepant 50, 100 mg Single-pulse transcranial magnetic stimulation Noninvasive vagus nerve stimulation Early vomiting Zolmitriptan 5 mg nasal spray Sumatriptan 25 mg PR Sumatriptan 6 mg SC Menses-related headache Prevention Ergotamine po at night Estrogen patches Rimegepant 75 mg po took during the menses Treatment Triptans Very rapidly developing symptoms Zolmitriptan 5 mg nasal spray Sumatriptan 6 mg SC Dihydroergotamine 1 mg IM Abbreviation: NSAIDs. nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.

questions.text: 24-year-old Mrs. Roy comes to the hospital due to headaches that she has had every few months for the past 6-7 years. She describes these as left-sided and throbbing; they are associated with mild nausea, last for 12-18 hours, and improve after she rests in a dark and quiet room or takes ibuprofen. For the past month, she has been waking up almost daily with bifrontal headaches often accompanied by nausea and vomiting. She also has occasional blurry vision. The patient attributes these headaches to increased stress at work after being promoted to a supervisor position. She has had no fevers, focal weakness, or numbness. She has no other medical history and does not use tobacco, alcohol, or recreational drugs. Her mother and sister have migraine headaches. Bilateral pupils are equal and reactive to light. She has a normal examination of the cranial nerves, motor strength, sensation, and deep tendon reflexes. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

MRI of the brain This patient has 2 different types of headache, one of which is likely a migraine (eg, infrequent, unilateral throbbing pain, mild nausea, improvement with rest ) that has been unchanged for years , and a new type that is different (eg, Bifrontal headache on awakening ) and associated with concerning symptom s (eg, nausea and vomiting, blurry vision). This patient's new headache and her associated symptoms are worrisome for elevated intracranial pressure (eg, from mass effect) and should be evaluated early with an MRI of the brain to determine the cause.

Highyeild:

Warning signs that suggest a serious underlying disorder: should lead to the consideration of early imaging: Neurologic findings Sudden-onset headache First severe headache “Worst” headache ever Vomiting that precedes headache Subacute worsening over days or weeks Pain induced by bending, lifting, coughing Pain that disturbs sleep or presents immediately upon awakening Known systemic illness Onset after age 55 Fever or unexplained systemic signs Abnormal neurologic examination Pain associated with local tenderness g., region of temporal artery Seizure changes in consciousness Differences compared to prior headaches Change in frequency, intensity, characteristics sudden onset trauma

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A.Gradual withdrawal of analgesics -However, this patient gives no indication that she is overusing analgesics , and rebound headaches are unlikely to cause daily bifrontal headaches with nausea, vomiting, and blurry vision . Option: C. Topiramate and as-needed sumatriptan- As needed sumatriptan with prophylactic topiramate would be appropriate in a patient suffering from frequent migraines , but this patient's new headache is different from her prior ones and warrants further evaluation first. Option: D.Inhaled oxygen and prophylactic verapamil - would be appropriate for a patient with cluster headaches .
